newsitem.title: INDIA: India, Bulgaria sign agreement to bolster trade.
newsitem.headline: India, Bulgaria sign agreement to bolster trade.

text.p: India and Bulgaria signed a trade agreement on Wednesday that officials said would boost commerce between the two nations.
Indian ambassador to Bulgaria Nirupam Sen told reporters in the Indian capital that the two countries had agreed to extend Most Favoured Nation (MFN) status to each other.
Under MFN, two countries agree to give each other the maximum tariff concessions on their mutual trade that they already grant to other countries.
"The new agreement was signed this morning between India and Bulgaria which aims at providing a new impetus to trade in the changing economic scenario in both the countries," Sen said.
Trade between India and Bulgaria fell to $16 million in 1993 from $90 million in 1985. It has since partly rebounded, and totalled some $55 million in 1995, Sen said.
But the value of Bulgarian exports to India is nearly five times greater than imports from India.

"Budget constraints, banking failures and losses from state enterprises have resulted in a resource crunch which has seriously limited our buying," visiting Bulgarian Trade Minister Atanas Paparizov said.
Paparizov said the situation was not sustainable, and Bulgaria would have to buy more goods from India.
India traditionally imports fertilisers, oil products and machinery from Bulgaria, and exports graphite, processed leather, soya flour, peppercorns and pharmaceutical goods.
Paparizov said both countries needed to concentrate less on trade in raw materials and more on value-added goods.
Officials of both countries expressed optimism that trade deals involving pharmaceuticals and antibiotics would be clinched.
